thread.title: At least four dead after whale-watching boat sinks off Vancouver Island
thread.title_full: At least four dead after whale-watching boat sinks off Vancouver Island | OregonLive.com

author: Michael Russell | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: At least four dead after whale-watching boat sinks off Vancouver Island
text:
Updated, 9 p.m.: At least four people have died after a whale-watching boat sank off Vancouver Island Sunday afternoon, Canadian officials are reporting.
The vessel, carrying 27 people, made a mayday call shortly before 4 p.m. near Tofino, British Columbia, according to the Toronto Star .
"We can definitely confirm we've been called to the dock in Tofino and we understand multiple fatalities," Coroner Barb McClintock told the newspaper.
Late Sunday, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported at least four people have died, while several more were taken to Tofino General Hospital. That number could increase, according to the BC Ambulance Service.
According to the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre in Victoria, the capsized boat, the MV Leviathan II, was operated by Jamie's Whaling Station of Tofino. The three-decked vessel , which can hold as many as 46 people, sank west of Vargas Island.
The Canadian Coast Guard was aided in their search by local water taxi companies and private vessels.
The mayor of Tofino, Josie Osborne, tweeted her condolences for the passengers, crew and their families .
#Tofino 's thoughts & prayers are with passengers, crew, emergency responders & their families. Thank you all for your messages of support.
— Josie Osborne (@Josie_Osborne) October 26, 2015 The Transportation Safety Board of Canada announced it was sending a crew to Tofino to investigate the incident.
TSB deploying a team of investigators to a marine accident in Tofino, BC https://t.co/JxCYzuM6Zz
— TSB of Canada (@TSBCanada) October 26, 2015 Keep an eye on OregonLive.com for more details on this breaking story.
-- Michael Russell
